ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: NEAT implementation details
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ken, ... thanks! ... ok that makes sense. If a node is not being connected to then throw it away. We can always add more in later. If I do go the way of

Hi Ken,

Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>Hi Colin, absolutely feel free to ask questions.  I think a C#
>implementation of NEAT would be great, and also I agree doing you own
>implementation will be educational. 
>
>  
>
thanks!

>Before I answer your questions, the general rule should be that all
>input nodes and all output nodes are always copied from parent(s) to
>child.  However, only hidden nodes that are connected to an inherited
>link should be copied to children.  
>
>  
>
ok that makes sense. If a node is not being connected to then throw it 
away. We can always add more in later. If I do go the way of 
distinguishing between input, hidden and output nodes then I would 
probably place the 3 node types in 3 different Vector(ArrayList in C#) 
structures - this avoids the additional task of having to seperate them 
out each time we want to decode the Genone into a Network

>>Some questions then:
>>
>>1) I see from your recent email that you (optionally) allow input 
>>nodes to be removed. Do you also allow input nodes to be added?
>>
>>    
>>
>
>In general, the previous posting was not meant to imply that input
>nodes are allowed to be removed.  They really should never be removed
>or added.  There should always be a constant set of possible inputs. 
>However, it is possible to start out with some *disconnected* input
>nodes, which later get "added" in the sense that a new connection
>appears that links them into the network.
>
>  
>
Got it. This really goes back to my previous email - we can consider 
input nodes to be connection points for the NN rather than proper 
working nodes. Do you agree?


>>4) Not really a question, just an observation. In your original
>>
[...]

>>It is true that only connection genes are used in measuring
>>compatibility, since as you observe connections never change the nodes
>>to which they connect.  Thus they are a sufficient set to determine
>>the network topology and compatibility.  
>>
>>    
>>
Understood.

>>It is also true that I used the same class NNode for node genes and
>>for actual neurons.  However, it is a subtle, but actually the NNodes
>>inside actual NN's are not literally the same NNodes in the genome. 
>>In other words, the NNodes in the networks are created separately,
>>although they do contain an "analogue" pointer back to the node gene
>>from which they were created.  Actually, I regret this slightly
>>confusing programming decision.  It would have been easier to
>>understand had a used a separate class for "node genes" and "actual
>>neurons."
>>
>>    
>>
My own philosophy (which often changes!) is that clear code is 
preferable to optimized/fast code, at least where experimentation is 
involved. Looking back at the EANN work I did 4 years ago was quite an 
eye opener I can tell you :)

>Good luck with your project.   Don't be discouraged if it's a bit of a
>learning curve starting up.  I'm sure several here can vouch that
>after the initial framework gets put in place things get easier and 
>more interesting.
>
>  
>
Ah well I think it's fair to say I'm not a /complete/ novice in this 
area but I appreciate the encouragment all the same, cheers!

Colin.
